help_workflow.explanation:
Rules are logically separated by the following types:
- **Global rules**: These rules apply to every command, regardless of group, sub-group or name.
- **Group rules**: These rules apply to entire command groups, such as "admin".
- **Sub-group rules**: These rules apply to a specific sub-group of a specific group, such as "commands".
- **Command rules**: These rules apply to specific commands, such as "help".
Each one of these groups may apply to all channels or a specific channel only.

The rule precedence is as follows: _global rules > group rules > sub-group rules > command rules_. Rules that apply to all channels are applied before those that apply to specific channels only.

For example, to allow the execution of commands in a single channel only, you would need two rules:
1. :no_entry: Forbid the execution of all commands in every channel.
2. :white_check_mark: Allow the execution of all commands in a specific channel.

match_users_workflow.description_base: This is what I think about the relationship between <@{user_id1}> and <@{user_id2}>:
descriptions:
_{love_type}_
This relationship is based on lust, so it won't work for anything serious.

_{love_type}_
This is just the kind of love between siblings.

_{love_type}_
While it may work, this is one really open relationship. Like some WiFi networks.

_{love_type}_
It feels almost as if I were looking at two best friends.

_{love_type}_
If you keep flirting just a little longer, this relationship may develop into something serious.

_{love_type}_
This relationship has reached a new high. It's the embodiment of love.
match_users_workflow.self_description:
_{love_type}_
Always love yourself, <@{user_id}>, you're a great addition to the world.
match_users_workflow.title: Matchmaker's Insight
